contextId.information: Your language may have a particular way of introducing the author of a letter. You may also need to tell in this same verse who the people are to whom Paul wrote the letter ([[:en:bible:notes:rom:01:07|1:7]]). AT: "I, Paul, wrote this letter" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Paul

contextId.information: Here the word "flesh" refers to the physical body. AT: "who is a descendant of David according to the physical nature" or "who was born into the family of David" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: who was born from the descendants of David according to the flesh

contextId.information: Paul wants to strengthen the Roman Christians spiritually. AT: "some gift that will help you to grow spiritually" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: some spiritual gift, in order to strengthen you

contextId.information: Here "believes" means that one puts his trust in Christ. AT: "it is through the gospel that God powerfully saves those who put their trust in Christ" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: it is the power of God for salvation for everyone who believes

contextId.information: Here "righteous" refers to those who trust in God. AT: "It is people who trust in God that he considers right with him, and they will live forever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: The righteous will live by faith

contextId.information: Here "truth" refers to true information about God. AT: "hide the true information about God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: hold back the truth

contextId.information: Here "enlightened them" means God has shown them the truth about him. AT: "Because God has shown everyone what he is like" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: For God has enlightened them

contextId.information: Here "a depraved mind" means a mind that thinks only about immoral things. AT: "God allowed their minds, which they had filled with worthless and immoral thoughts, to completely control them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: he gave them up to a depraved mind

contextId.information: Here "practice" refers to continually or habitually doing things that are evil. AT: "and that those who keep on doing wicked things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: that those who practice such things

contextId.information: Here the verb "do" refers to continuing to do things that are evil. AT: "who keep on doing evil things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: who do them

contextId.information: The word "therefore" marks a new section of the letter. It also makes a concluding statement based on what Paul said in [[:en:bible:notes:rom:01:32|1:1-32]]. AT: "Since God will punish those who continually sin, he will certainly not excuse your sins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Therefore you are without excuse

contextId.information: Paul uses the word "person" here to scold anyone who might think he can act like God and judge others. AT: "You are just a human being, yet you judge others and say they deserve God's punishment" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: you person, you who judge

contextId.information: Here "the law" refers to the law of Moses. AT: "it is not those who only hear the law of Moses" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: it is not the hearers of the law

contextId.information: Here "revelation" refers to God's words and promises. You can translate this in an active form. AT: "God gave his words that contain his promises to the Jews" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: the Jews were entrusted with revelation from God

contextId.information: God will always be true and will keep his promises. AT: "God always does what he has promised" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: let God be found to be true

contextId.information: Here "human logic" refers to the way humans would normally speak. AT: "I am saying here what people would normally say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: I am speaking according to human logic

contextId.information: There is no one who understands what is right. AT: "No one really understands what is right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: There is no one who understands

contextId.information: Since no one does what is good, they are useless to God. AT: "Everyone has become useless to God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: They together have become useless

contextId.information: Paul implies that God accepts all people in the same way. AT: "There is no difference at all between the Jews and the Gentiles" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: For there is no distinction

contextId.information: Here "justified" refers to being made right with God. You can translate this in an active form. AT: "God has made them right with himself as a free gift, because Christ Jesus has set them free" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: They are freely justified by his grace through the redemption that is in Christ Jesus

contextId.information: Here "righteousness of the faith" means that God considered him to be righteous. AT: "a visible sign that God considered him righteous because he had believed in God before he was circumcised" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: a seal of the righteousness of the faith that he had already possessed when he was in uncircumcision

contextId.information: Here "of him whom he trusted" refers to God. AT: "Abraham was in the presence of God whom he trusted, who gives life to those who have died" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Abraham was in the presence of him whom he trusted, that is, God, who gives life to the dead

contextId.information: The full meaning of "outward circumstances" can be made explicit. AT: "Even though it seemed impossible for him to have descendants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Despite all outward circumstances

contextId.information: Here "justified" means that God puts us in a right relationship with himself. You can translate this in an active form. AT: "How much more will God do for us now that he has made us right with himself because of the death of Jesus on the cross" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Much more, then, now that we are justified by his blood

contextId.information: This means that God did not charge the people with sinning before he gave the law. AT: "but God recorded no sin against the law before he gave the law" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: but there is no accounting for sin when there is no law

contextId.information: Here "one" refers to Adam. AT: "For if by one man's sin, many died" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: For if by the trespass of the one the many died

contextId.information: Here "grace" refers to God's free gift that he made available to everyone through Jesus Christ. AT: "even more through the man Jesus Christ, who died for us all, did God kindly offer us this gift of everlasting life, although we do not deserve it" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: much more did the grace of God and the gift by the grace of the one man, Jesus Christ, abound for the many

contextId.information: Here "the gift" refers to God's freely erasing the record of our sins. AT: "The gift is not like the result of Adam's sin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: For the gift is not like the outcome of the one who sinned

contextId.information: Here Paul gives two reasons why "the gift is not like the result of Adam's sin." The phrases "For on the one hand" and "but on the other hand" introduce two different ways of thinking about something. The "judgment of condemnation" implies that we all deserve God's punishment for our sins. AT: "Because on the one hand, God declared that all people deserve to be punished because of the sin of one man, but on the other hand" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: For on the one hand, the judgment of condemnation came because of the trespass of one man. But on the other hand

contextId.information: Here "condemnation" refers to God's punishment. AT: "all people deserve God's punishment for sin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: all people came to condemnation

contextId.information: Here "justification" refers to God's ability to make people right with him. AT: "God's offer to make all people right with him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: the justification of life for all people

contextId.information: Here "died" refers to the fact that believers are no longer controlled by sin. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: we have died with Christ

contextId.information: To be "under law" means to be subject to its limitations and weaknesses. You can make the full meaning explicit in your translation. AT: "For you are no longer bound to the law of Moses, which could not give you the power to stop sinning" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: For you are not under law

contextId.information: Here "condemnation" refers to punishing people. AT: "God will not condemn and punish those who are joined to Christ Jesus" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: There is therefore now no condemnation for those who are in Christ Jesus

contextId.information: This refers to God's Spirit. AT: "God's Spirit in Christ Jesus" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: the principle of the Spirit of life in Christ Jesus

contextId.information: How Christ lives in a person could be made explicit. AT: "If Christ lives in you through the Holy Spirit" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: If Christ is in you

contextId.information: Here "our adoption" means when we become full members of God's family, as adopted children. The word "redemption" means when God saves us. AT: "waiting for when we are fully members of God's family and he saves our bodies from decay and death" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: waiting for our adoption, the redemption of our body

contextId.information: This refers to God. Here "searches the hearts" means "examines our thoughts and feelings." AT: "God, who knows all our thoughts and feelings" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: He who searches the hearts

contextId.information: Here "brothers" refers to all believers, both male and female. AT: "among many brothers and sisters who belong to the family of God" ([[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: among many brothers

contextId.information: Here "justified" is in the past tense to emphasize that this will certainly happen. AT: "these he also put right with himself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: these he also justified

contextId.information: You can make explicit the kind of love that Jesus showed. AT: "because of Jesus, who loved us so much he was willing to die for us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: through the one who loved us

contextId.information: Here "Christ has come with respect to the flesh" means that Christ is a physical descendant of the Israelite ancestors. AT: "Christ has come physically as a descendant from their ancestors" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Theirs are the ancestors from whom Christ has come with respect to the flesh

contextId.information: Here "glory" refers to life in heaven with God. AT: "whom he prepared ahead of time in order that they might live with him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: which he had previously prepared for glory

contextId.information: Here "he" refers to God. AT: "As God says also in the book that Hosea wrote" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: As he says also in Hosea

contextId.information: You can indicate that Isaiah wrote this. You can also translate it in an active form. AT: "as Isaiah the prophet wrote" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: as it has been written

contextId.information: Here "righteousness refers to the way God puts people right with himself. You can make this explicit in the translation. AT: "For they do not know how God puts people right with himself" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: For they do not know of God's righteousness

contextId.information: Here "believes" means "trusts." AT: "in order that he may make everyone who trusts in him right before God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: for righteousness for everyone who believes

contextId.information: In order to be made right with God through the law, a person would have to keep the law perfectly, which is not possible. AT: "The person who perfectly obeys the law will live because the law will make him right before God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: The man who does the righteousness of the law will live by this righteousness

contextId.information: Paul implies that God will treat all people the same. You can make this explicit in your translation. AT: "In this way, God treats the Jews and the non-Jews the same" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: For there is no difference between Jew and Greek

contextId.information: Here "without understanding" means that the people do not know God. AT: "By a nation with people who do not know me or my commands" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: By means of a nation without understanding

contextId.information: Paul continues to explain how God's mercy works. AT: "But since God's mercy works by grace" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: But if it is by grace

contextId.information: God will save those who believe. AT: "Perhaps some will believe and God will save them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Perhaps we will save some of them

contextId.information: Paul does not want the Gentile believers to think they are wiser than the Jewish unbelievers. AT: "so that you will not think you are wiser than you are" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: in order that you will not be wise in your own thinking

contextId.information: You can make explicit that God treated the Jews as enemies because they rejected Jesus. AT: "because the Jews rejected the good news about Christ" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: concerning the gospel

contextId.information: This expresses Paul's desire for all people to honor God. You can make this explicit in your translation. AT: "May all people honor him forever!" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: To him be the glory forever

contextId.information: Here "brothers" refers to fellow believers, both male and female. AT: "Fellow believers, because of the great mercy that God has given you I very much want you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: I urge you therefore, brothers, by the mercies of God

contextId.information: Here "grace" refers to God's choosing Paul to be an apostle and leader of the church. You can make this explicit in your translation. You can also translate this in an active form. AT: "because God freely chose me to be an apostle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: because of the grace that was given to me

contextId.information: Paul implies here that believers have different abilities that correspond to their faith in God. AT: "since God has given each of you different abilities because of your trust in him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: just as God has given out to each one a certain amount of faith

contextId.information: Here "giving" refers to giving money and other things to people. You can make this meaning  explicit in your translation. AT: "If one has the gift of giving money or other goods to people in need" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: If one's gift is giving

contextId.information: Paul implies here that the believers can be confident that God will help them. AT: "Be happy because you are confident that God will always help you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Rejoice in the confidence you have about the future

contextId.information: You can make the full meaning explicit. You can also translate this in an active form. AT: "Let each person be sure what he is doing is to honor the Lord" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Let each person be convinced in his own mind

contextId.information: Here "lives for himself" means to live only to please oneself. AT: "None of us should live merely to please ourselves" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: For none of us lives for himself

contextId.information: Paul implies here that a person should stay away from anything that he thinks is unclean. You can make this explicit in your translation. AT: "But if a person thinks something is unclean, then for that person it is unclean and he should stay away from it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Only for him who considers anything to be unclean, for him it is unclean

contextId.information: Paul argues that God set up his kingdom so he could give us a right relationship with himself, and to provide peace and joy. AT: "For God did not set up his kingdom so that he could rule over what we eat and drink. He set up his kingdom so we could have a right relationship with him, and so he could give us peace and joy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: For the kingdom of God is not about food and drink, but about righteousness, peace, and joy in the Holy Spirit

contextId.information: Here "build up one another" refers to helping each other grow in faith. AT: "let us seek to live peacefully together and help one another grow stronger in faith" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: let us pursue the things of peace and the things that build up one another

contextId.information: Anything that is "not from faith" is something that God does not want you to do. You can make explicit the full meaning here. AT: "you are sinning if you do something that you do not believe God wants you to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: whatever is not from faith is sin

contextId.information: Here "strong" refers to the people who are strong in their faith. They believe that God allows them to eat any kind of food. AT: "we who are strong in faith" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: we who are strong

contextId.information: Here "the weak" refers to the people who are weak in their faith. They believe that God does not allow them to eat some kinds of food. AT: "those who are weak in faith" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: the weak

contextId.information: Here Paul refers to a scripture where Christ (the Messiah) speaks to God. You can translate this in an active form. AT: "the Messiah said to God in the scriptures" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: it was just as it is written

contextId.information: Here "have confidence" means that the believers will know that God will fulfill his promises. You can make explicit the full meaning in your translation. AT: "In this way the scriptures will encourage us to expect that God will do for us everything that he has promised" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: in order that through patience and through encouragement of the scriptures we would have confidence

contextId.information: Here "him" refers to the descendant of Jesse, the Messiah. Those who are not Jews will also trust him to fulfill his promises. AT: "The people who are not Jews can trust him to do what he has promised" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: The Gentiles will have confidence in him

contextId.information: Here "confidence" refers to one's ability to trust in God to do what he has promised to do. AT: "God, whom you trust to fulfill his promises" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: the God of confidence

contextId.information: Paul is quite sure that the believers in Rome are honoring each other in their behavior. AT: "I myself am completely sure that you yourselves have acted toward others in a completely good way" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: I myself am also convinced about you, my brothers

contextId.information: Here "the things of God" could refer to the task that God has chosen Paul to do. AT: "Therefore I have reason to rejoice in Christ Jesus and in the work God has given me to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: So my delight is in Christ Jesus and in the things of God

contextId.information: Paul implies that there are no more places in these areas where people live who have not heard about Christ. AT: "there are no more places in these regions where people have not heard about Christ" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: I no longer have any place in these regions

contextId.information: Here Paul implies that he wants the Roman believers to provide some financial assistance to him for his journey to Spain. AT: "that you will help me on my journey" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: to be sent on my way by you

contextId.information: The "God of peace" means the God who causes believers to have inner peace. AT: "I pray that God who causes all of us to have inner peace" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: May the God of peace

contextId.information: Paul encourages the Roman believers to welcome Phoebe as a fellow believer. AT: "welcome her because we all belong to the Lord" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: receive her in the Lord

contextId.information: Paul's "fellow workers" are people who also tell others about Jesus. AT: "who work with me to tell people about Christ Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: my fellow workers in Christ Jesus

contextId.information: This refers to those who trust in Jesus. AT: "who are believers" or "who belong to the Lord" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: who are in the Lord

contextId.information: This refers to those who argue and cause others to stop trusting in Jesus. AT: "who are causing believers to argue with one another and to stop having faith in God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: who are causing the divisions and stumbling

contextId.information: Here the word "grace" refers to the Lord's blessings upon his people. AT: "May the Lord Jesus Christ continue to act kindly toward you all" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: May the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you all
